title: 110_s763
content: The Act may be cited as the "Public Transportation Terrorism Prevention Act of 2007". Congress finds that public transportation systems worldwide have been targets of terrorist attacks, with over 6,000 agencies operating in the US and 33 million daily passengers. Significant investments have been made by the Federal Transit Administration for construction and improvements, as well as funding for aviation and public transportation security measures. The Federal Transit Administration has made significant investments in public transportation security measures, with only $0.008 per passenger boarding allocated for this purpose. SEC. 3. SECURITY ASSESSMENTS. The Federal Transit Administration must submit public transportation security assessments to the Secretary within 30 days of the Act's enactment. The Secretary will review and enhance these assessments by July 31, 2007. The assessments will be used to allocate grant funds unless adjustments are needed for urgent threats or significant factors. The Secretary of Homeland Security, in consultation with public transportation systems and state/local officials, must establish security improvement priorities by September 30, 2007. Updates to security assessments and new assessments for all public transportation systems are required by July 31, 2008, and annually thereafter. The Secretary of Homeland Security must conduct security assessments for public transportation agencies at high risk of terrorist attacks. The information collected will be used to develop security guidelines and strategies to minimize threats and maximize mitigation efforts. Additionally, security assessments for bus and rural public transportation systems must be completed by July 31, 2007. The Secretary of Homeland Security conducts security assessments for public transportation systems, including local bus-only systems and those receiving funds under section 5311 of title 49, to determine specific needs. SEC. 4. SECURITY ASSISTANCE GRANTS. The Secretary awards grants to public transportation agencies for capital security improvements, including tunnel protection systems, perimeter protection systems, critical operations control systems, detection systems, surveillance equipment, communications equipment, emergency response equipment, fire suppression equipment, and global positioning systems. The Secretary awards grants for capital security improvements such as tunnel protection systems, perimeter protection systems, critical operations control systems, detection systems, surveillance equipment, communications equipment, emergency response equipment, fire suppression equipment, and global positioning systems. Additionally, grants are provided for operational security improvements including security training, drills, and public awareness campaigns. The Secretary awards grants for various security improvements, including public awareness campaigns, canine patrols for detection, overtime reimbursement for security personnel during events, and other identified security enhancements. Coordination with State Homeland Security Plans is essential in establishing priorities and awarding grants for capital and operational security improvements. The Secretary ensures security improvements are consistent with State Homeland Security Plans. For multi-state transportation systems, risks of the entire system are considered in establishing security priorities and awarding grants. Congressional notification is required before awarding any grants. The Senate committee requires public transportation agencies receiving grants to appoint a security coordinator, develop a maintenance plan, and report annually on grant funds usage. Grantees must return misspent funds to the Treasury if used for unauthorized purposes. SEC. 5. PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION SECURITY TRAINING PROGRAM. The Secretary must develop regulations for a public transportation worker security training program within 90 days of enactment. The program will prepare workers for potential threat conditions and include elements such as determining the seriousness of occurrences. The regulations require public transportation systems to develop security training programs addressing seriousness of occurrences, communication, defense responses, protective devices, evacuation procedures, psychology of terrorists, situational training exercises, and other relevant subjects. The Act mandates the development of a public transportation worker security training program that must be submitted to the Secretary for approval. The Secretary has 30 days to review and approve the program or request revisions. Public transit agencies must respond to the Secretary's comments within 30 days. Within 1 year of approval, the public transportation system owner or operator must complete the training program. The transportation system owner or operator must complete training for all public transportation workers according to the approved program. The Secretary will review the program's implementation in a sample of transportation systems and report to relevant committees. The Secretary will update training regulations periodically. The regulations require public transportation systems to update their security programs and provide additional training to workers in response to new threats. Operators must revise their programs and train frontline workers promptly after any updates to the regulations. SEC. 6. INTELLIGENCE SHARING. The Secretary of Homeland Security ensures timely notification of terrorist threats to public transportation assets in the US. Financial assistance is provided for the Information Sharing and Analysis Center for Public Transportation to protect critical infrastructure. Public transportation agencies at significant risk of terrorist attack are required to participate. The Secretary of Homeland Security ensures timely notification of terrorist threats to public transportation assets in the US. Public transportation agencies at significant risk of terrorist attack are required to participate in the ISAC without any fees. SEC. 7. RESEARCH, DEVELOPMENT, AND DEMONSTRATION GRANTS AND CONTRACTS. The Secretary, through the Homeland Security Advanced Research Projects Agency, will award grants or contracts for research and demonstration of technologies to reduce terrorist threats in public transportation systems. Funds can be used for research on detection systems and imaging technologies. The Homeland Security Advanced Research Projects Agency will award grants or contracts for research on technologies to reduce terrorist threats in public transportation systems. Entities receiving grants must report annually on fund usage and return misspent funds to the Treasury if used for unauthorized purposes. The Homeland Security Advanced Research Projects Agency will award grants or contracts for research on technologies to reduce terrorist threats in public transportation systems. Entities receiving grants must report annually on fund usage and return misspent funds to the Treasury if used for unauthorized purposes. SEC. 8. REPORTING REQUIREMENTS. The Secretary must submit a semi-annual report to Congress by March 31 and September 30 each year. The report should include details on the implementation of specific provisions, funds appropriated for sections 3 through 6, and any unexpended or unobligated funds. The Secretary must submit an annual report to Governors by March 31, detailing the grant funds distributed to public transportation agencies and their use. Authorization of appropriations. Authorization of appropriations for various security assistance programs including Capital Security Assistance Program, Operational Security Assistance Program, Intelligence, and Research. Appropriations for fiscal years 2008, 2009, and 2010 are specified for each program. Authorization of appropriations for security assistance programs includes Capital Security Assistance Program, Operational Security Assistance Program, Intelligence, and Research. Funding allocated for fiscal years 2008, 2009, and 2010 are $30,000,000, $45,000,000, and $55,000,000 respectively. The authority to make grants under this Act will expire on October 1, 2011.
